hints.content:
*Rotational symmetry* means that we can rotate a figure a certain number of degrees around a point, and the figure will be unchanged.

Performing the rotation brings the starting point to $(-9,1)$. If the rotation leaves the quadrilateral unchanged, this new point must also be on the original quadrilateral.

![](https://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/6f185159549d28ac0f0c0594b4d867a16db61e2c.png)

We can perform the rotation again to map $(-9,1)$ to $(-9,-9)$. Then we do it once more to map $(-9,-9)$ to $(1,-9)$.  The final rotation shows us that point $(1,-9)$ maps back to our original point $(1,1)$.

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/a4aacf1e11d7accbf17e4b4c5067eba951c7c6bb)

The original quadrilateral is a square.

![](https://ka-perseus-images.s3.amazonaws.com/8fa46c185be9c1d54f5ebca3f4182d87690466ac.png)

question.content:
One of the points that defines a certain quadrilateral is $(1,1)$. The quadrilateral has rotational symmetry of $90^\circ$ about the point $(-4,-4)$.

**Draw and classify the quadrilateral described above.**  
(Choose the most specific description.)

[[☃ interactive-graph 1]]

[[☃ radio 1]]

hints.content:
*Reflective (or line) symmetry* means that we can reflect a figure across a line, and the figure will remain unchanged.

Performing the reflection over $y=-x+6$ brings the starting point to $(3,-2)$. If the reflection leaves the quadrilateral unchanged, this new point must also be on the original quadrilateral.

![](https://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/e904e316a6471bdb3bf9a4a4760e21cace9c5bba.png)

Performing the reflection over $y=x$ brings the point $(3,-2)$ to $(-2,3)$ and the point $(8,3)$ to $(3,8)$. These points must also be on the original quadrilateral.

![](https://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/0941730607beef2287def41a6b4ab5915b08475b.png)

The original quadrilateral is a square.

![](https://ka-perseus-images.s3.amazonaws.com/68b8503acdc10f616a3645487012fe7784fea403.png)

hints.content:
*Rotational symmetry* means that we can rotate a figure a certain number of degrees around a point, and the figure will be unchanged.

Performing the rotation brings the starting point to $(5,2)$. If the rotation leaves the quadrilateral unchanged, this new point must also be on the original quadrilateral.

![](https://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/020af52b949f9cfd31c0e034c85cc903637ad630.png)

*Reflective (or line) symmetry* means that we can reflect a figure across a line, and the figure will remain unchanged.

Performing the reflection over $y=-x$ brings the point $(-9,2)$ to $(-2,9)$ and the point $(5,2)$ to $(-2,-5)$. These new points must also be on the original quadrilateral.

![](https://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/2eaaeaa1407d767bfd59623226be3f22d8620122.png)

The original quadrilateral is a square.

hints.content:
*Rotational symmetry* means that we can rotate a figure a certain number of degrees around a point, and the figure will be unchanged.

Performing the rotation brings the starting points to $(0,-9)$ and $(-3,-5)$. If the rotation leaves the hexagon unchanged, these new points must also be on the original hexagon.

![](https://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/32e5a06f1f0d49b965f45b54a5cafcbb54d55e12.png)

*Reflective (or line) symmetry* means that we can reflect a figure across a line, and the figure will remain unchanged.

Performing the reflection takes $(3,5)$ to $(3,-5)$, $(0,9)$ to $(0,-9)$ and vice versa, and $(-3,-5)$ to $(-3,5)$. These points must also be on the original hexagon.

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/6ea312fc5aa3d5f757533914a2c34f36e14de942)

This is the correct hexagon.

![](https://ka-perseus-images.s3.amazonaws.com/43002aaa789cfa3e88ec6d0bc40f1a7147c4a74b.png)

question.content:
Two of the points that define a certain hexagon are $(0,9)$ and $(3,5)$. The hexagon has the following symmetries:

* rotational symmetry of $180^\circ$ about the origin
* reflective symmetry over the line $y=0$

**Draw the hexagon described above.**  

[[☃ interactive-graph 1]]

hints.content:
*Rotational symmetry* means that we can rotate a figure a certain number of degrees around a point, and the figure will be unchanged.

Performing the rotation brings the starting point to $(-7, 3)$. If the rotation leaves the octagon unchanged, this new point must also be on the original octagon.

![](https://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/e3a0f2a1101ea9d871933771045bf9a4a08f4f7b.png)

*Reflective (or line) symmetry* means that we can reflect a figure across a line, and the figure will remain unchanged.

Performing the reflection over $y=0$ takes $(3,7)$ to $(3,-7)$ and $(-7,3)$ to $(-7,-3)$. These points must also be on the original octagon.

![](https://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/d4a3c23d184dfe8f7beb9fbc2c5e413529a23ced.png)

Performing the reflection over $x=0$ reveals four more points that must also be on the original octagon.  Point $(3,7)$ maps to $(-3,7)$, point $(-7,3)$ maps to $(7,3)$, point $(-7,-3)$ maps to $(7,-3)$, and point $(3,-7)$ maps to $(-3,-7)$.

![](https://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/c614b5a54b1a597e038d29b3e50e33886c06e54f.png)

This is the correct octagon.

![](https://ka-perseus-images.s3.amazonaws.com/c24d212a56aa5e89a9ae7c6cb138558d57ef84fe.png)

question.content:
One of the points that defines a certain octagon is $(3,7)$. The octagon has the following symmetries:

* rotational symmetry of $90^\circ$ about the origin
* reflective symmetry over the line $y=0$
* reflective symmetry over the line $x=0$

**Draw the octagon described above.**  

[[☃ interactive-graph 1]]

hints.content:
*Reflective (or line) symmetry* means that we can reflect a figure across a line, and the figure will remain unchanged.

Performing the reflection over $y=\dfrac x2$ takes $(0,5)$ to $(4,-3)$. If the reflection leaves the quadrilateral unchanged, this point must also be on the original quadrilateral.

![](https://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/0774092e578ce12335b12157f43921647f932b90.png)

Performing the reflection over $y=-2x + 5$ takes $(-4,-2)$ to $(8,4)$. This point must also be on the original quadrilateral.

![](https://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/b7f9bfd9350dc434126baa4cedd00876c838a39e.png)

We can readily see that this is some kind of parallelogram, based on the slopes of its sides, and it clearly does not have right angles.

To determine whether or not it is a rhombus, we can examine the lengths of the sides. By doing that, we find that the figure is a **rhombus**. [[☃ explanation 1]]

options.explanation:
Let's use the variable $\purple c$ for the length from $(-4,-2)$ to $(0,5)$, and the variable $\red d$ for the length from $(0,5)$ to $(8,4)$.  To find the length of each line segment, we can extend horizontal and vertical lines from the endpoints, constructing a right triangle.

Using the Pythagorean theorem, we have:

>$\begin{align}
\purple{c}^2&=\purple{4}^2+\purple{7}^2&&&\red{d}^2&=\red{1}^2+\red{8}^2\\
\purple{c}^2&=65&&&\red{d}^2&=65\\
\purple{c}&=\purple{\sqrt{65}}&&&\red{d}&=\red{\sqrt{65}}
\end{align}$

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/bcd1e0b42ac9f3489d4ced5d57cc0514e6789a6b)

Because each side of the parallelogram is the same length, the most specific description of the figure is a **rhombus**.

hints.content:
The original quadrilateral is a rhombus.

![](https://ka-perseus-images.s3.amazonaws.com/ccc1e61110eb0c3548af8dcce83df154e530e386.png)

question.content:
Two of the points that define a certain quadrilateral are $(-4,-2)$ and $(0,5)$. The quadrilateral has the following symmetries:

* reflective symmetry over the line $y=\dfrac x2$
* reflective symmetry over the line $y=-2x + 5$

**Draw and classify the quadrilateral described above.**  
(Choose the most specific description.)

[[☃ interactive-graph 1]]

[[☃ radio 1]]

hints.content:
*Rotational symmetry* means that we can rotate a figure a certain number of degrees around a point, and the figure will be unchanged.

Performing the rotation brings the starting points to $(1,-4)$ and $(-9,-6)$. If the rotation leaves the quadrilateral unchanged, these new points must also be on the original quadrilateral.

![](https://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/7920e6e3826a870e1b5325801f88cd6241194802.png)

We can readily see that this is some kind of parallelogram, based on the slopes of its sides, and it clearly does not have right angles.

To determine whether or not it is a rhombus, we can examine the lengths of the sides. By doing that, we find that the figure is a **parallelogram** and **not** a rhombus. [[☃ explanation 1]]

options.explanation:
Let's use the variable $\purple c$ for the length from $(-9,-6)$ to $(-3,0)$, and the variable $\red d$ for the length from $(-3,0)$ to $(7,2)$.  To find the length of each line segment, we can extend horizontal and vertical lines from the endpoints, constructing a right triangle.

Using the Pythagorean theorem, we have:

>$\begin{align}
\purple{c}^2&=\purple{6}^2+\purple{6}^2&&&\red{d}^2&=\red{10}^2+\red{2}^2\\
\purple{c}^2&=72&&&\red{d}^2&=104\\
\purple{c}&=\purple{6\sqrt{2}}&&&\red{d}&=\red{2\sqrt{26}}
\end{align}$

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/f51a63cd96adc4ccdcd0cc955d4601dc34da0dd6)

Because the sides of the parallelogram are not all congruent and there are no right angles, the most specific description of the figure is a **parallelogram**.

hints.content:
The original quadrilateral is a parallelogram.
![](https://ka-perseus-images.s3.amazonaws.com/7a48b4c7e46224d72a1b99c474db983362883051.png)

question.content:
Two of the points that define a certain quadrilateral are $(-3,0)$ and $(7,2)$. The quadrilateral has rotational symmetry of $180^\circ$ about the point $(-1, -2)$.

**Draw and classify the quadrilateral described above.**  
(Choose the most specific description.)

[[☃ interactive-graph 1]]

[[☃ radio 1]]

hints.content:
*Reflective (or line) symmetry* means that we can reflect a figure across a line, and the figure will remain unchanged.

Let's check the reflection over $y=-\dfrac{2}{3}x$. 

The line $y=-\dfrac{2}{3}x$ goes through the center of the nonagon and one of the corner points $(6,-4)$. Since this nonagon is regular, it's unchanged by a reflection over this line.  Thus, the figure is **symmetric** over this line.

![](https://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/fa396a6d2acc1440754ac42d26f6dde11c004dcd.png)

[alternate image, but labels are misplaced on Perseus.
web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/d6b6a17461d9791908d3298014104c6776074c64]:

Let's check the reflection over $y=-x$. 

Since the line does not pass through either a vertex or the midpoint of a side of the figure, the nonagon is **not symmetric** over this line.  While the angles and side lengths remain the same, the position has changed.

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/936d391175acb17be31c389d0862f4ff44bf91e9)

*Rotational symmetry* means that we can rotate a figure a certain number of degrees around a point, and the figure will be unchanged.  

Let's check the rotation of $40^\circ$ about the origin. There are $9$ congruent sides.

$\qquad \dfrac{360^\circ}{9} = 40^\circ$

The figure remains unchanged, so it is **symmetric** about the origin at this magnitude of rotation.

![](https://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/e6ff347a7ba3576c93761593a7bd56a4e14fdc92.png)

The symmetries that this figure has are:

* Reflective symmetry over the line $y=-\dfrac23 x$
* Rotational symmetry of $40^\circ$ about the origin

question.content:
**Which of the following symmetries does the regular nonagon below have?**  
(The nonagon is centered at the origin.)

[[☃ categorizer 1]]

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/98865d4ccb4d06aacf62722fbc145c25e41b8323)

items: Reflection symmetry over the line $y=-\dfrac23 x$
Rotational symmetry of $40^\circ$ about the origin
रेखा $y=-x$ के परितः परावर्तक सममिति

hints.content:
*Reflective (or line) symmetry* means that we can reflect a figure across a line, and the figure will remain unchanged.

Let's check the reflection over $y=x$. 

Under this transformation, each point on the star maps to another point which is no longer on the star.  The star is **not symmetric** over this line.

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/68c0740ebe681cff02da5ee1f67df247006d3722
)

*Rotational symmetry* means that we can rotate a figure a certain number of degrees around a point, and the figure will be unchanged.

There are $10$ congruent sides, but only two groups of $5$ congruent angles.  Thus if the figure repeats at all, it must repeat $5$ times in a full $360^\circ$ rotation.

$\qquad \dfrac{360^\circ}{5} = 72^\circ$

The figure remains unchanged with a $72^\circ$ rotation, so the figure is symmetric with that magnitude of rotation about the origin. Do either of the given rotations leave the figure unchanged?

![](https://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/77e943feb33ac4c5cd7ed38d4f97e705bd75b640.png)

Since the figure is unchanged by a rotation of $72^\circ$, it will also be unchanged by *a second* rotation of $72^\circ$. This means it will be unchanged by a rotation of $72^\circ+72^\circ = 144^\circ$ about the same center.

The same is true for any multiple of $72^\circ$ about the origin.  Which rotations are multiples of $72^\circ$?

The symmetries that apply to the star are:

* Rotational symmetry of $288^\circ$ about the origin

question.content:
**Which of the following symmetries apply to the the star below?**  
(The star is centered at the origin.)

[[☃ categorizer 1]]




![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/e6eda096c4ee127fe2e7db6d70ce21ecac423698)

items: Rotational symmetry of $62^\circ$ about the origin
Rotational symmetry of $288^\circ$ about the origin
Reflective symmetry over the line $y=x$

hints.content:
*Reflective (or line) symmetry* means that we can reflect a figure across a line, and the figure will remain unchanged.

Let's check the reflection over $y=-\dfrac{7}{3}x$. 

The line $y=-\dfrac{7}{3}x$ goes through two of the opposite corner points $(-3, 7)$, and $(3,-7)$. Since this hexagon is regular, it's unchanged by a reflection over this line.

![](https://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/544a9864d4ceac796e882bdfdff5de792e300dfe.png)

*Rotational symmetry* means that we can rotate a figure a certain number of degrees around a point, and the figure will be unchanged.

Let's check the rotation of $60^\circ$ about the origin. There are $6$ congruent sides.

$\qquad  \dfrac{360^\circ}{6} = 60^\circ $

The figure remains unchanged, so the figure is **symmetric** with that magnitude of rotation about the origin.  Do any other rotations leave the figure unchanged?

![](https://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/b7a3ea1fb1943f80c5e0c73ec80f2ded1531327f.png)

Since the figure is unchanged by a rotation of $60^\circ$, it will also be unchanged by *a second* rotation of $60^\circ$. This means it will be unchanged by a rotation of $60^\circ+60^\circ = 120^\circ$ about the same center.

The same is true for any multiple of $60^\circ$ about the origin.

The symmetries that apply to the regular hexagon are:

* Reflective symmetry over $y=-\dfrac{7}{3}x$
* Rotational symmetry of $60^\circ$ about the origin
* Rotational symmetry  of $120^\circ$ about the origin

question.content:
**Which symmetries apply to this regular hexagon?**  
(The hexagon is centered at the origin.)

[[☃ categorizer 1]]




![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/86802147134b78fa5d1948559135c2919b8c123d)

items: Reflective symmetry over the line $y=-\dfrac{7}{3}x$
Rotational symmetry of $60^\circ$ about the origin
Rotational symmetry of $120^\circ$ about the origin

hints.content:
*Reflective (or line) symmetry* means that we can reflect a figure across a line, and the figure will remain unchanged.

Let's check the reflection over $y= x$. 

The points $(8, 8)$ and $(-6,-6)$ are on this line, so they are unchanged by the reflection. 

The line $y=x$ is the perpendicular bisector of the segment connecting points $(-5,0)$ and $(0,-5)$, so this reflection causes those two points to switch places.

The kite is left unchanged, so it is **symmetric** over this line. Does the other reflection leave the kite unchanged?

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/c4f01ac02e00844d1b9812ba5fd3a4aac23cd061)

Let's check for reflective symmetry over the line $y=-x-5$.

The points $(-5,0)$ and $(0,-5)$ are on this line, so they are unchanged by the reflection. 

However, the points $(8,8)$ and $(-6,-6)$ map to points that are not vertices of the original kite, so the kite is **not symmetric** over that line.

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/ff6c76a591aba81ceee23b8aed170d3e6cfe8399)

Let's check the rotation of $180^\circ$ about the origin.

Because this figure has $2$ angles which have unique measurements, the figure cannot have rotational symmetry.

Some points on the kite map to points which are not on the figure. The kite is changed by this transformation, so it is **not symmetric**.

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/eb25fa286edc1d3dc77667498874c5c580ec4cdf)

The symmetry that applies to this kite is:

* Reflective symmetry over the line $y=x$

question.content:
**Which of the following symmetries apply to the kite below?**  

[[☃ categorizer 1]]

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/765deea6467f5372193dce9b9c7584df395a885f)

items: Rotational symmetry of $180^\circ$ about the origin
Reflective symmetry over $y=x$
Reflective symmetry over $y=-x-5$

hints.content:
*Reflective (or line) symmetry* means that we can reflect a figure across a line, and the figure will remain unchanged.

Let's check the reflection over $y=-2x$. 

The points $(2, -4)$ and $(-2,4)$ are on this line, so they are unchanged by the reflection. 

The line $y=-2x$ is the perpendicular bisector of the segment connecting points $(8,4)$ and $(-8,-4)$, so this reflection causes those two points to switch places.

The rhombus is left unchanged, so it is **symmetric** over this line. Does the other reflection leave the rhombus unchanged?

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/12ced224ee9e91ea1c8f3e6ef2dadb283ec62eb4)

Let's check the reflection over $y=\dfrac{1}{2}x$. 

The points $(-8, -4)$ and $(8,4)$ are on this line, so they are unchanged by the reflection. 

The line $y=\dfrac{1}{2}x$ is the perpendicular bisector of the segment connecting points $(-2,4)$ and $(2,-4)$, so this reflection causes those two points to switch places.

The rhombus is left unchanged, so it is **symmetric** over this line. 

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/5d4d8524689049a7bc4f27940a39a88c229faac7)

*Rotational symmetry* means that we can rotate a figure a certain number of degrees around a point, and the figure will be unchanged.

Let's check the rotation of $180^\circ$ about the origin.

Under this rotation, the points $(8,4)$ and $(-8,-4)$ switch places. Also, the points $(2, -4)$ and $(-2,4)$ switch places.

The rhombus remains unchanged, so it is **symmetric** for a rotation of this magnitude about the origin. 

![](https://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/4c6ffdfa0f63310bdf142027af2027437243849c.png)

The symmetries that apply to this rhombus are:

* Reflective symmetry over the line $y=-2x$
* Reflective symmetry over the line $y=\dfrac12x$
* Rotational symmetry of $180^\circ$ about the origin

question.content:
**Which of the following symmetries apply to the rhombus below?**  

[[☃ categorizer 1]]

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/b92d5c7754a0c80d6b2af70b24ed368eeb16bb1e)

items: Rotational symmetry of $180^\circ$ about the origin
Reflective symmetry over the line $y=-2x$
Reflective symmetry over the line $y=\dfrac{1}{2}x$

hints.content:
*Reflective (or line) symmetry* means that we can reflect a figure across a line, and the figure will remain unchanged.

Let's check the reflection over $y=-x$. 

The point $(4, -4)$ is on this line, so it is unchanged by the reflection. 

However, the points $(-8,-4)$ and $(4,6)$ map to points that are not vertices of the original figure.

The right triangle is changed, so it is **not symmetric** over this line. 

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/b81754cf7a6cd98b76842e50b41324dc3808910b)

*Rotational symmetry* means that we can rotate a figure a certain number of degrees around a point, and the figure will be unchanged.

Because there are no congruent line segments in this figure, the only rotation that would map the right triangle to itself is a $360^\circ$ rotation, which is not considered a kind of symmetry.  The right triangle is **not symmetric** for any rotational symmetry.

[[☃ explanation 1]]

options.explanation:
Let's check the rotation of $90^\circ$ about the point $(1,-1)$.

Under this rotation, $(4,6)$ and $(-8,-4)$ map to points that are not on the original figure.

The figure changes, so it is __not symmetric__ for a rotation of this magnitude about the point $(1,-1)$. 

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/6a2dc4a842784ea032dbc77a0ca93ce64a99a273)

Likewise, we see the rotation of $120^\circ$ about the point $(1,-1)$.

Again, the figure changes, so it is __not symmetric__ for a rotation of this magnitude. 

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/6e3e7d008ee876ca89a40a1ca3f8b4a62e33d92c)

hints.content: The right triangle is not symmetric for any of the given symmetries.

question.content:
**Which of the following symmetries apply to the right triangle below?**  

[[☃ categorizer 1]]

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/9a685a1a193fa969539a2b385bd7dd6e6187a583)

items: Rotational symmetry of $90^\circ$ about the point $(1,-1)$
रेखा $y=-x$ के परितः परावर्तक सममिति
Rotational symmetry of $120^\circ$ about the point $(1,-1)$

hints.content:
*Reflective (or line) symmetry* means that we can reflect a figure across a line, and the figure will remain unchanged.

Let's check the reflection over $y=-\dfrac{2}{3}x$. 

The line $y=-\dfrac{2}{3}x$ goes through the center of the triangle and one of the corner points $(6,-4)$. Since this triangle is regular, it's unchanged by a reflection over this line.  Thus, the figure is **symmetric** over this line.

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/82e2279aef59d5dbe071b8a8b4893bde35835335)

Let's check the reflection over $x=0$. 

Since the line does not pass through either a vertex or the midpoint of a side of the figure, the figure is **not symmetrical** over this line.  While the angles and side lengths remain the same, the position has changed.

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/9858e3a8e49706bdbf5f1f3fda69eecbc05d513d)

*Rotational symmetry* means that we can rotate a figure a certain number of degrees around a point, and the figure will be unchanged.  

There are $3$ congruent sides.  Thus if the figure repeats at all, it must repeat $3$ times in a full $360^\circ$ rotation.

$\qquad \dfrac{360^\circ}{3} = 120^\circ$

The figure remains unchanged, so it is **symmetric** with this magnitude of rotation about the origin.

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/25d525081e85286acf76c781a66c5d258d648e8b)

Since the figure is unchanged by a rotation of $120^\circ$, it will also be unchanged by *a second* rotation of $120^\circ$. This means it will be unchanged by a rotation of $120^\circ+120^\circ = 240^\circ$ about the same center.

The triangle has rotational **symmetry**  for a rotation of any multiple of $120^\circ$ about the origin.

The symmetries that apply to the equilateral triangle are:

* Reflective symmetry over the line $y=-\dfrac23 x$
* Rotational symmetry of $240^\circ$ about the origin

question.content:
**Which of the following symmetries does the equilateral triangle below have?**  
(The triangle is centered at the origin.)

[[☃ categorizer 1]]

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/e33fe39ee2e89f3f5d3cae7ebdf69efe5dcd5a23)

items: Reflection symmetry over the line $y=-\dfrac23 x$
Rotational symmetry of $240^\circ$ about the origin
Reflective symmetry over the line $x=0$

hints.content:
*Reflective (or line) symmetry* means that we can reflect a figure across a line, and the figure will remain unchanged.

Let's check the reflection over $y=4$. 

The point $(7,4)$ is on this line, so it is unchanged by the reflection. 

However, the points $(4,0)$ and $(3,7)$ map to points that are not on the original figure.

While the angles and side lengths remain the same, the position has changed.  So, the right triangle is **not symmetric** over this line. 

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/96950d3777da443471f829cebabd44367bbfec3e)

Let's check the reflection over $y=\dfrac{1}{7}x+3$. 

The point $(7,4)$ is on the line, so it is unchanged by the reflection.

The line $y=\dfrac{1}{7}x+3$ is the perpendicular bisector of the segment connecting points $(3,7)$ and $(4,0)$, so this reflection causes those two points to switch places.

The triangle is left unchanged, so it is **symmetric** over this line.

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/606a17066eb7de8697e1436027194c36df11cfc5)

*Rotational symmetry* means that we can rotate a figure a certain number of degrees around a point, and the figure will be unchanged.

Because there is one side with a unique length, the only rotation that would map the right triangle to itself is a $360^\circ$ rotation, which is not considered a kind of symmetry.  The right triangle is **not symmetric** for any rotational symmetry.

The symmetry that applies to the right triangle is:

- Reflective symmetry over the line $y=\dfrac{1}{7}x+3$

**Which of the following symmetries apply to the right triangle below?**

Reflective symmetry over the line $y=4$
Rotational symmetry of $180^\circ$ about the point $(7,4)$

hints.content:
*परावर्तक (या रैखिक) सममिति* का अर्थ यह है कि हम एक आकृति को किसी रेखा के परितः परावर्तित कर सकते हैं, और आकृति में कोई बदलाव नहीं आएगा।

हम $y=-x$ के परितः परावर्तन की जाँच करेंगे। 

रेखा $y=-x$, बिंदुओं $(-1,8)$ और $(-8,1)$ को जोड़ने वाले रेखाखंड की लंब समद्विभाजक है, इसलिए यह परावर्तन इन दो बिंदुओं के स्थान आपस में बदल देता है।

 इसी प्रकार, यह बिंदुओं $(6,-1)$ और $(1,-6)$ को जोड़ने वाले रेखाखंड की लंब समद्विभाजक है, इसलिए यह परावर्तन इन दो बिंदुओं के स्थान आपस में बदल देता है।

समलंबाभ में कोई बदलाव नहीं आता है, इसलिए वह इस रेखा के परितः **सममित** है। क्या दूसरा परावर्तन के बाद समलंबाभ अप्रभावित रहता है?

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/05c104d96e1afb6eb732c1646ee2a29bd45a4496)

हम $y=-7x+1$ के परितः परावर्तन की जाँच करेंगे। 

बिंदु $(-1,8)$ और $(1,-6)$ इस रेखा पर स्थित हैं, इसलिए वे परावर्तन के बाद अप्रभावित रहेंगे। 

परंतु, बिंदु $(-8,1)$ और $(6,-1)$ उन बिंदुओं पर प्रतिचित्रित होते हैं जोकि मूल समलंबाभ पर नहीं हैं, इसलिए दिया गया समलंबाभ इस रेखा के परितः **सममित नहीं** है।

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/23af0b0544855316c3079e01c5b77ec0c8e536ae)

*घूर्णन सममिति* का अर्थ यह है कि हम एक आकृति को किसी बिंदु के चारों ओर कुछ डिग्री तक घुमा सकते हैं, और आकृति में कोई बदलाव नही आएगा।  

हम बिंदु $(-1,1)$ के सापेक्ष $90^\circ$ के घूर्णन की जाँच करेंगे।

क्योंकि इस आकृति के पास $2$ भुजाएँ ऐसी हैं जिनकी लंबाई अद्वितीय है, इसलिए इस आकृति के पास घूर्णन सममिति नहीं हो सकती है।

समलंबाभ के कुछ बिंदु उन बिंदुओं पर प्रतिचित्रित होते हैं जोकि आकृति पर नहीं हैं। इस परावर्तन के बाद समलंबाभ बदल चुका है, इसलिए वह **सममित नहीं** है।

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/2bf8e2a5303cc6b9bd39fff45e196e247895ee51)

दिए गए समद्विबाहु समलंबाभ पर निम्नलिखित सममितियाँ लागू होती हैं:

* रेखा $y=-x$ के परितः परावर्तक सममिति

question.content:
**निम्नलिखित में से कौन सी सममितियाँ नीचे दिए गए समद्विबाहु समलंबाभ में लागू होती हैं?**  

[[☃ categorizer 1]]

रेखा $y=-x$ के परितः परावर्तक सममिति
रेखा $y=-7x+1$ के परितः परावर्तक सममिति

hints.content:
*Reflective (or line) symmetry* means that we can reflect a figure across a line, and the figure will remain unchanged.

Let's check the reflection over $y=\dfrac{5}{3}x$. 

The points $(3,5)$ and $(-3,-5)$ are on this line, so they are unchanged by the reflection. 

However, the points $(7,1)$ and $(-7,-1)$ map to points that are not on the original figure.

The parallelogram has changed, so it is **not symmetric** over this line. 

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/87c4e6385d978e452aebe08f1136fca710f0ed7e)

Let's check the reflection over $y=\dfrac{3}{5}x$. 

The line $y=\dfrac{3}{5}x$ neither passes through any vertices of the parallelogram nor forms a perpendicular bisector to any of its sides.

While the angles and side lengths remain the same, the position has changed.  So the parallelogram is **not symmetric** over this line.

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/8fb1a4a983e9f127e07498d926df7a73176321a3)

*Rotational symmetry* means that we can rotate a figure a certain number of degrees around a point, and the figure will be unchanged.

Let's check the rotation of $180^\circ$ about the origin.

Under this rotation, $(7,1)$ and $(-7,-1)$ switch places. Also, $(3,5)$ and $(-3,-5)$ switch places.

The figure remains unchanged, so it is **symmetric** for this magnitude about the origin. 

![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/7edf8edcf7d53544ee743a36f6dc7c8901a65c21)

The symmetry that applies to the parallelogram is:

- Rotational symmetry of $180^\circ$ about the origin

items: Reflective symmetry over the line $y=\dfrac{5}{3}x$
Reflective symmetry over the line $y=\dfrac{3}{5}x$
Rotational symmetry of $180^\circ$ about the origin

hints.content:
*Line symmetry* means that we can reflect a figure across a line, and the figure will remain unchanged.

The figure below shows the lines of symmetry that cause the rectangle to map to itself.

>![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/67cce91ce34d9ee9e98d4f92f953042478e60e7e)

*Rotational symmetry* means that we can rotate a figure a certain number of degrees around a point, and the figure will be unchanged. 

We know that for the figure to be unchanged, any line segment would have to map onto a congruent line segment.  Further, the congruent segments must repeat in the same order around the center, like repeated designs on a wheel.

A rectangle has pairs of $2$ congruent line segments.  Thus if it repeats at all, it must repeat $2$ times in a full $360^\circ$ rotation.

>$\dfrac{360^\circ}{2} = 180^\circ$

>![](https://ka-perseus-images.s3.amazonaws.com/d7a42a40ac8305e9d791aa817f72a75f1b8e5818.gif)

We see that a $180^\circ$ rotation would map every point of the rectangle to itself.  [[☃ explanation 1]]

options.explanation: The second arrow represents another rotation of $180^\circ$, meaning that we would have rotated the figure a full $360^\circ$.  *Every* figure maps onto itself if it turns a full circle, so we do not call this a kind of symmetry.

hints.content:
- The rectangle has $2$ lines of symmetry.

- The rectangle has rotational symmetry about the point for a magnitude of $180^\circ$.

question.content:
**How many lines of symmetry does the rectangle below have?**

[[☃ radio 2]]

**Which of the following are magnitudes for rotational symmetry of the rectangle below about the marked point?**

[[☃ radio 1]]


>![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/2f4c6924fd8245939c92f7ed2379787c68a4d9b6)

hints.content:
*Line (or reflective) symmetry* means that we can reflect a figure across a line, and the figure will remain unchanged.

The figure below shows the line of symmetry that causes the isosceles trapezoid to map to itself.

>![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/f664920e2e700879ad91ef7e6097bcdc642b994e)

*Rotational symmetry* means that we can rotate a figure a certain number of degrees around a point, and the figure will be unchanged. 

We know that for the figure to be unchanged, any line segment would have to map onto a congruent line segment.  Further, the congruent segments must repeat in the same order around the center, like repeated designs on a wheel.

Because this figure has $2$ sides which have unique lengths, the figure cannot have rotational symmetry.

>![](https://ka-perseus-images.s3.amazonaws.com/8e275ec8b813162427cf94d29ad22e7b3775a61d.gif)

- The isosceles trapezoid has $1$ line of symmetry.

- None of the above.  The isosceles trapezoid does not have rotational symmetry.

**How many lines of symmetry does the isosceles trapezoid below have?**

choices.content: The isosceles trapezoid does not have rotational symmetry.

hints.content:
*Line (or reflective) symmetry* means that we can reflect a figure across a line, and the figure will remain unchanged.

The figure below shows the lines of symmetry that cause the hexagon to map to itself.

>![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/dae996f3b1b0fd7b9b92d99c3a72d2b266819cb2)

*Rotational symmetry* means that we can rotate a figure a certain number of degrees around a point, and the figure will be unchanged. 

We know that for the figure to be unchanged, any line segment would have to map onto a congruent line segment.  Further, the congruent segments must repeat in the same order around the center, like repeated designs on a wheel.

The hexagon has $6$ congruent line segments, but two sets of $3$ congruent angles.  Thus if it repeats at all, it must repeat $3$ times in a full $360^\circ$ rotation.

[Do I need an explanation here proving that the other 3 angles are congruent to each other?]:

>$\dfrac{360^\circ}{3} = 120^\circ$

>![](https://ka-perseus-images.s3.amazonaws.com/399bc973773bd55518c0cbab94b9c31bf5597cd3.gif)

We see that a $120^\circ$ rotation would map every point of the hexagon to itself.  What other rotations will leave the hexagon unchanged?  [[☃ explanation 1]]

options.explanation:
The second arrow represents another rotation of $120^\circ$, meaning that we would have rotated the figure a total of $240^\circ$.  Every additional rotation of $120^\circ$ that sums to less than $360^\circ$ represents another valid magnitude of rotational symmetry for the figure.  *Every* figure maps onto itself if it turns a full circle, so we do not call this a kind of symmetry.

This hexagon has rotational symmetry around the center at magnitudes of:

- $120^\circ$
- $240^\circ$

hints.content:
- The hexagon has $3$ lines of symmetry.

- The hexagon has rotational symmetry about the point for a magnitude of $120^\circ$ and $240^\circ$.

*Line (or reflective) symmetry* means that we can reflect a figure across a line, and the figure will remain unchanged.

The figure below shows the line of symmetry that causes the quadrilateral to map to itself.

>![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/740aaa9a16137d7a63ce210be6ee57ad0f1167fb)

*Rotational symmetry* means that we can rotate a figure a certain number of degrees around a point, and the figure will be unchanged. 

We know that for the figure to be unchanged, any line segment would have to map onto a congruent line segment.  Further, the congruent segments must repeat in the same order around the center, like repeated designs on a wheel.

Because this figure has $2$ angles which have unique measurements, the figure cannot have rotational symmetry.

>![](https://ka-perseus-images.s3.amazonaws.com/a063d5b46834b4004e5d757cfc3186007a8bccb4.gif)

- The quadrilateral has $1$ line of symmetry.

- None of the above.  The quadrilateral does not have rotational symmetry.

hints.content:
*Line symmetry* means that we can reflect a figure across a line, and the figure will remain unchanged.

Every diameter of a circle is a line of symmetry, and a diagonal can pass through any point on  the circle.  Thus, there are an unlimited number of lines of symmetry for a circle.

The figure below shows a few (but not all) of the lines of symmetry.

>![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/504e474b731d0217fdb1adb9ba6f2851a6436f25)

*Rotational symmetry* means that we can rotate a figure a certain number of degrees around a point, and the figure will be unchanged. 

We know that for the figure to be unchanged, any point would have to map onto another point in the figure.  By definition, every point in a circle is an equal distance from the center.

Since the circle includes points a full $360^\circ$ around the center, the circle has **every magnitude** of rotational symmetry.

- The circle has unlimited lines of symmetry.

- Of the choices, the circle has rotational symmetry about the point for magnitudes of $7^\circ$, $45^\circ$, $90^\circ$, $210^\circ$, and $355^\circ$.

**How many lines of symmetry does the circle below have?**

[[☃ radio 1]]


>![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/629a41064808fc2cfce9701b00cf7a214402440c)

hints.content:
*Line symmetry* means that we can reflect a figure across a line, and the figure will remain unchanged.

The figure below shows the lines of symmetry that cause the ellipse to map to itself.

>![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/2885a7cf07a5f03d073ee51674f4a60c73eebf8f)

*Rotational symmetry* means that we can rotate a figure a certain number of degrees around a point, and the figure will be unchanged. 

We know that for the figure to be unchanged, any point would have to map onto another point, an equal distance from the center.

An ellipse has $2$ points which are at a greater distance from the center than all other points on the ellipse.  Thus if it repeats at all, it must repeat $2$ times in a full $360^\circ$ rotation.

>$\dfrac{360^\circ}{2} = 180^\circ$

>![](https://ka-perseus-images.s3.amazonaws.com/7943c345d04934236844782ecaa5d2090e22dc58.gif)

We see that a $180^\circ$ rotation would map every point of the ellipse to itself.  [[☃ explanation 1]]

options.explanation: The second arrow represents another rotation of $180^\circ$, meaning that we would have rotated the figure a full $360^\circ$.  *Every* figure maps onto itself if it turns a full circle, so we do not call this a kind of symmetry.

hints.content:
- The ellipse has $2$ lines of symmetry.

- The ellipse has rotational symmetry about its center for a magnitude of $180^\circ$.

question.content:
**How many lines of symmetry does the ellipse below have?**

hints.content:
*Line (or reflective) symmetry* means that we can reflect a figure across a line, and the figure will remain unchanged.

The figure below shows the lines of symmetry that cause the regular pentagon to map to itself.

>![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/71103769686b664a714cae9b7d1baa757ccbdd56)

*Rotational symmetry* means that we can rotate a figure a certain number of degrees around a point, and the figure will be unchanged. 

We know that for the figure to be unchanged, any line segment would have to map onto a congruent line segment.  Further, the congruent segments must repeat in the same order around the center, like repeated designs on a wheel.

A regular pentagon has $5$ congruent line segments and $5$ congruent angles.  Thus if it repeats at all, it must repeat $5$ times in a full $360^\circ$ rotation.

>$\dfrac{360^\circ}{5} = 72^\circ$

>![](https://ka-perseus-images.s3.amazonaws.com/47dcde4e90ea6e8709091876dffb6cda8e03b1af.gif)

We see that a $72^\circ$ rotation would map every point of the pentagon to itself.  What other rotations will leave the pentagon unchanged?  [[☃ explanation 1]]

options.explanation:
The second arrow represents another rotation of $72^\circ$, meaning that we would have rotated the figure a total of $144^\circ$.  Every additional rotation of $72^\circ$ that sums to less than $360^\circ$ represents another valid magnitude of rotational symmetry for the figure.  *Every* figure maps onto itself if it turns a full circle, so we do not call this a kind of symmetry.

The regular pentagon has rotational symmetry around the center at magnitudes of:

- $72^\circ$
- $144^\circ$
- $216^\circ$
- $288^\circ$

hints.content:
- The regular pentagon has $5$ lines of symmetry.

- Of the choices available, the regular pentagon has rotational symmetry about its center for a magnitude of $72^\circ$, $144^\circ$, and $216^\circ$.

hints.content:
*Line (or reflective) symmetry* means that we can reflect a figure across a line, and the figure will remain unchanged.

The figure below shows the lines of symmetry that cause the square to map to itself.

>![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/f6fbcffbbe347945d82e0336eebabdcdf96508d9)

*Rotational symmetry* means that we can rotate a figure a certain number of degrees around a point, and the figure will be unchanged. 

We know that for the figure to be unchanged, any line segment would have to map onto a congruent line segment.  Further, the congruent segments must repeat in the same order around the center, like repeated designs on a wheel.

A square has $4$ congruent line segments and $4$ congruent angles.  Thus if it repeats at all, it must repeat $4$ times in a full $360^\circ$ rotation.

>$\dfrac{360^\circ}{4} = 90^\circ$

>![](https://ka-perseus-images.s3.amazonaws.com/87973ad9759dbba8024b05ba28408cb12f3be1e0.gif)

We see that a $90^\circ$ rotation would map every point of the square to itself.  What other rotations will leave the square unchanged?  [[☃ explanation 1]]

options.explanation:
The second arrow represents another rotation of $90^\circ$, meaning that we would have rotated the figure a total of $180^\circ$.  Every additional rotation of $90^\circ$ that sums to less than $360^\circ$ represents another valid magnitude of rotational symmetry for the figure.  *Every* figure maps onto itself if it turns a full circle, so we do not call this a kind of symmetry.

The square has rotational symmetry around the center at magnitudes of:

- $90^\circ$
- $180^\circ$
- $270^\circ$

hints.content:
- The square has $4$ lines of symmetry.

- Of the choices available, the square has rotational symmetry about the point for a magnitude of $180^\circ$ and $270^\circ$.

The figure below shows the lines of symmetry that cause the regular octagon to map to itself.

>![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/5c57e3b607fef6f8548d9eb338cb0220294ee237)

*Rotational symmetry* means that we can rotate a figure a certain number of degrees around a point, and the figure will be unchanged. 

We know that for the figure to be unchanged, any line segment would have to map onto a congruent line segment.  Further, the congruent segments must repeat in the same order around the center, like repeated designs on a wheel.

A regular octagon has $8$ congruent line segments and $8$ congruent angles.  Thus if it repeats at all, it must repeat $8$ times in a full $360^\circ$ rotation.

>$\dfrac{360^\circ}{8} = 45^\circ$

>![](https://ka-perseus-images.s3.amazonaws.com/640aa30720444e705fa541a7b2688a850b48b185.gif)

We see that a $45^\circ$ rotation would map every point of the octagon to itself.  What other rotations will leave the octagon unchanged?  [[☃ explanation 1]]

options.explanation:
The second arrow represents another rotation of $45^\circ$, meaning that we would have rotated the figure a total of $90^\circ$.  Every additional rotation of $45^\circ$ that sums to less than $360^\circ$ represents another valid magnitude of rotational symmetry for the figure.  *Every* figure maps onto itself if it turns a full circle, so we do not call this a kind of symmetry.

The regular octagon has rotational symmetry around the center at magnitudes of:

- $45^\circ$
- $90^\circ$
- $135^\circ$
- $180^\circ$
- $225^\circ$
- $270^\circ$
- $315^\circ$

hints.content:
- The regular octagon has $8$ lines of symmetry.

- Of the choices available, the regular octagon has rotational symmetry about the point for a magnitude of $45^\circ$, $180^\circ$, and $225^\circ$.

question.content:
**How many lines of symmetry does the regular octagon below have?**

[[☃ radio 2]]

**Which of the following are magnitudes for rotational symmetry of the regular octagon below about the marked point?**

[[☃ radio 1]]


>![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/1410de8d4424e1dbd310d4b2cff69a4bd1e9e711)

hints.content:
*Line symmetry* means that we can reflect a figure across a line, and the figure will remain unchanged.

There are no lines of symmetry for the parallelogram.  For example, suppose we had a line that passed through the upper left and lower right vertices.  We see that reflecting across this line does **not** map the parallelogram to itself.

>![](web+graphie://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/5fdd65ab588ed4710b11d8b12a6ea10afb6aacc4)

*Rotational symmetry* means that we can rotate a figure a certain number of degrees around a point, and the figure will be unchanged. 

We know that for the figure to be unchanged, any line segment would have to map onto a congruent line segment.  Further, the congruent segments must repeat in the same order around the center, like repeated designs on a wheel.

A parallelogram has pairs of $2$ congruent line segments.  Thus if it repeats at all, it must repeat $2$ times in a full $360^\circ$ rotation.

>$\dfrac{360^\circ}{2} = 180^\circ$

>![](https://ka-perseus-images.s3.amazonaws.com/8386d0cc0f4851dd8091ba0d497824fd08eba5e5.gif)

We see that a $180^\circ$ rotation would map every point of the parallelogram to itself.  [[☃ explanation 1]]

options.explanation: The second arrow represents another rotation of $180^\circ$, meaning that we would have rotated the figure a full $360^\circ$.  *Every* figure maps onto itself if it turns a full circle, so we do not call this a kind of symmetry.

hints.content:
- The parallelogram has $0$ lines of symmetry.

- The parallelogram has rotational symmetry about the point for a magnitude of $180^\circ$.
